definition: An affiliate is any company that controls
applicable_to: or is under common control with a financial institution. Control means ownership or power to direct management and policies. Affiliate disclosure and information sharing subject to GLBA Privacy Rule restrictions.
organization_owner: Per GLBA Section 101(b), affiliate means any company that controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with the financial institution. Control defined as: direct or indirect ownership of 25% or more of voting shares, or power to direct management and policies regardless of ownership percentage, or interlocking directors/executive officers. Affiliate identification is critical for GLBA compliance because affiliates may share customer information under specific GLBA conditions without customer consent. Affiliate information sharing allowed only for: servicing customer accounts, underwriting credit or insurance, or other affiliate transactions permitted by regulation. Institution must identify all affiliates, disclose affiliate relationships in privacy notice, manage affiliate information sharing through privacy opt-out mechanisms. Affiliate relationship affects consumer opt-out rights: customers may opt-out of information sharing with affiliates for marketing purposes; opt-out applies to all affiliates. Affiliate information sharing requires: customer prior consent or affiliate opt-out election, or information used for account servicing, credit underwriting, or permitted affiliate transactions. Non-affiliate service providers: vendors, agents, and service providers may not be treated as affiliates; different rules apply. Insurance agency affiliate: insurance agencies of bank holding companies are affiliates; insurance information sharing subject to opt-out. Securities affiliate: brokerage subsidiaries are affiliates; securities information sharing subject to rules. Data integrity: affiliate list maintained and updated; changes documented; new affiliates identified; divested entities removed from affiliate list.

column12: Affiliate Definition: Section 101(b) Analysis: Any company that controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with a financial institution constitutes an affiliate. Control definition: direct or indirect ownership of 25% or more of voting securities; power to direct management and policies regardless of ownership level; interlocking directors or officers; common control through parent entity. Examples: Bank holding company owns bank - both entities are affiliates; parent company owns two banks - both banks are affiliates of each other; insurance subsidiary of bank holding company is affiliate of bank; securities subsidiary is affiliate. Exclusions from affiliate definition: service providers/vendors (different rules apply); agents of the institution; customers or creditors unless they meet control definition. Affiliate Identification Process: Step 1 - Ownership Review: review organizational structure; identify parent company if any; identify subsidiaries; identify sister entities; review ownership documents; board minutes. Step 2 - Control Assessment: assess whether 25%+ ownership exists; assess management control regardless of ownership; assess common board members or officers; assess contractual control relationships. Step 3 - Documentation: document all affiliates; create affiliate list; list company names, legal entities, ownership percentages; document control relationships; maintain organizational chart. Step 4 - Update Procedures: review regularly (at least annually); update when new companies acquired; update when entities divested; update when control changes; document all changes. Step 5 - Communication: ensure all relevant staff aware of affiliate relationships; compliance staff trained; customer service staff understand affiliate relationships; vendor management trained. Affiliate Categories: Bank Holding Company Affiliate: parent company of bank; owns bank shares; controls bank policies; shares information with bank. Subsidiary Affiliate: subsidiary of bank or holding company; separate legal entity; controlled by parent; information sharing permitted. Sister Company Affiliate: another subsidiary of same parent company; common control through parent; affiliates of each other. Insurance Affiliate: insurance company subsidiary of financial services company; affiliate relationship; insurance information sharing rules apply. Securities Affiliate: brokerage or investment company subsidiary; affiliate relationship; securities information sharing rules apply. Financial Services Affiliate: finance company, loan company, real estate company subsidiary; affiliate relationship applies. International Affiliate: foreign subsidiary or parent of U.S. financial institution; affiliate relationship applies; cross-border information sharing considerations. Information Sharing with Affiliates: Permitted Without Opt-Out: servicing customer accounts (account maintenance, processing transactions); credit or insurance underwriting; fraud prevention; legal compliance. Permitted With Opt-Out Right: marketing solicitations about affiliate products or services; joint marketing; affiliate product offerings. Opt-Out Mechanics: customer must be informed of affiliate sharing; customer can opt-out of sharing for marketing; opt-out applies to all affiliates; opt-out honored before sharing. Privacy Notice Requirement: privacy notice must disclose: whether customer information is shared with affiliates; what affiliates do with information; what customers can do to opt-out; how to exercise opt-out; opt-out mechanisms (mail, phone, online). Affiliate List in Privacy Notice: some institutions list affiliates in privacy notice; privacy notice identifies categories of affiliates; privacy notice may reference website for complete list; privacy notice provides mechanism to request affiliate list. Customer Communication: clear explanation of affiliate relationships; clear explanation of information sharing; clear explanation of opt-out rights; customer questions answered; dispute procedures if customer disputes affiliate determination. Non-Affiliate Service Providers: Service provider vendors not affiliates; information sharing with service providers different rules; service providers not parties to affiliate information sharing; institutional affiliate rules don't apply to vendors; vendor contracting requirements instead. Affiliate vs. Joint Venture: joint venture may or may not be affiliate; depends on control; less than 50% ownership typically not affiliate; common control analysis determines affiliate status. Examination Focus: examiners verify: affiliate list completeness; affiliate identification accuracy; control assessment appropriateness; privacy notice affiliate disclosure; opt-out implementation; affiliate information sharing compliance; documentation of affiliate relationships. Common Examination Issues: incomplete affiliate identification; failure to disclose affiliate relationships; affiliate list outdated; inaccurate control assessment; inadequate privacy notice disclosure; non-compliant affiliate information sharing; inadequate opt-out procedures.

definition: Procedures for sharing customer information with affiliates and managing customer opt-out elections. Includes privacy notice disclosure
version: Per GLBA Section 502 and Regulation P (12 CFR 1016.2), institutions may share nonpublic personal information with affiliates for account servicing, credit underwriting, and certain affiliate transactions without prior opt-out if customer relationship exists. However, institutions must provide notice of affiliate sharing and opt-out right, particularly for marketing uses of information. Affiliate information sharing procedures: disclose in privacy notice, provide opt-out mechanism, honor opt-out elections, prevent sharing with opted-out affiliates, maintain opt-out records, update procedures when affiliates change. Opt-out right: customers may opt-out of sharing for marketing purposes; opt-out applies to all affiliates; opt-out must be honored; institution responsible for ensuring affiliates honor opt-out.
status: All financial institutions with affiliates; applies to all customer relationships; applies to all information sharing with affiliates; applies regardless of institution size; mandatory for compliance
key_features: Chief Privacy Officer for opt-out program; Chief Compliance Officer for oversight; Customer Service for opt-out election processing; IT for opt-out system implementation; Affiliates for honoring opt-out elections
column11: GLBA Section 502 (15 USC 6802) information sharing and opt-out; Regulation P (12 CFR 1016.2) affiliate opt-out procedures; FTC guidance on opt-out mechanics; Federal Reserve guidance on affiliate information sharing; OCC guidance on affiliate opt-out implementation
column12: Mandatory requirement; subject to examination; opt-out procedures must be clearly disclosed; institution liable if affiliate violates opt-out; audit opt-out compliance; examination will test opt-out procedures
column13: Affiliate Information Sharing Procedures: Permitted Information Sharing: account servicing (information needed to maintain accounts, process transactions, customer service); credit underwriting (information for credit decisions, credit risk assessment, pricing); insurance underwriting (information for insurance decisions, pricing); fraud prevention (information for fraud detection, prevention, loss mitigation); legal compliance (information required by law or regulation, tax compliance). Marketing Information Sharing: information about affiliate products and services; marketing solicitations using affiliate information; joint marketing with affiliates; requires opt-out right. Customer Notification: privacy notice discloses affiliate sharing; notice explains what information shared; notice explains with whom information shared; notice explains customer can opt-out; notice provides opt-out mechanism; notice provided at account opening and annually. Opt-Out Mechanisms: mail opt-out (address provided); telephone opt-out (number provided); online opt-out (website); in-person opt-out at branch; written opt-out; automated systems accepted. Opt-Out Election Process: customer exercises opt-out through one of provided mechanisms; customer provides identification (account number, name, address); opt-out confirmed to customer; opt-out recorded in system; opt-out implemented within required timeframe (typically 30 days); confirmation provided to customer. Opt-Out Record Maintenance: maintain record of customer opt-out elections; record includes: customer identification, opt-out date, information shared with whom, effective date, duration (ongoing unless revoked); records retained per policy (minimum 2 years). Opt-Out Effectiveness: institution ensures affiliates honor opt-out; contractual requirement; audit procedures; periodic testing; affiliate certification of opt-out honoring; customer dispute resolution if affiliate violates opt-out. Shared Affiliate Information Management: information sharing protocols established with affiliates; agreements include: opt-out honor requirement, security safeguards, limited use for specified purposes, no further sharing. Data Access Controls: restrict affiliate access to customer information; only to extent necessary for specified purposes; access controls enforced; logging of affiliate access; audit of affiliate information use. Joint Marketing: if institution and affiliate jointly market; shared information only for that marketing; customer can opt-out of joint marketing; notice required; opt-out right honored. Affiliate Information Requests: affiliates request information from institution; procedure for review of request; determination of whether sharing permitted; documentation of sharing decisions; customer communication if appropriate. Affiliate Mergers/Acquisitions: when affiliates merge or new affiliates acquired; update affiliate list; update privacy notice; review customer opt-out elections; ensure new affiliate honors existing opt-outs; notify customers of changes if material. Opt-Out Changes: customer may revoke opt-out; customer may change opt-out; procedures for modification documented; new elections honored; confirmation provided. Non-Affiliate Service Providers: service providers not subject to affiliate information sharing rules; different contractual requirements; service providers don't receive information under affiliate exception. Examination Focus: examiners test opt-out procedures; request sample of opt-out elections; verify affiliates honor opt-outs; review opt-out records; verify privacy notice disclosure; test customer service knowledge of opt-out procedures; verify timeliness of opt-out implementation. Common Issues: inadequate privacy notice disclosure; unclear opt-out mechanisms; slow opt-out implementation; affiliates not honoring opt-outs; inadequate opt-out record maintenance; inadequate customer communication.

node_name: Affiliate Disclosure and Privacy Notice Requirements
definition: Disclosure of affiliate relationships and information sharing in privacy notices provided to customers. Includes identification of affiliates
version: Per GLBA Section 502 and Regulation P (12 CFR 1016.4), financial institutions must disclose in privacy notices whether they share customer information with affiliates and provide customers opportunity to opt-out of such sharing (except for service/transaction purposes). Privacy notice must clearly identify: whether customer information is shared with affiliates, what types of affiliates, what information is shared, what the affiliates do with information, how customers can opt-out, how often customers can opt-out. Privacy notice requirements: clear and conspicuous, delivered at account opening and annually, accurate and complete, includes all material information about information sharing practices, describes customer rights.
status: All financial institutions; all customers with account or ongoing relationship; applies to all account types; applies to all information sharing scenarios; mandatory compliance
key_features: Chief Privacy Officer for notice drafting; Legal counsel for notice accuracy; Compliance for notice review; Customer Service for notice distribution; Marketing for notice content
column11: GLBA Section 502 (15 USC 6802) notice requirements; Regulation P (12 CFR 1016.4) privacy notice standards; FTC guidance on notice content and form; Federal Reserve guidance on notice requirements; OCC guidance on affiliate disclosure; CFPB guidance on UDAAP implications
column12: Mandatory requirement; notice must be accurate and complete; subject to examination; inaccurate notice results in enforcement action; notice must be updated annually; examiner will compare notice to actual practices
column13: Privacy Notice Content: Affiliate Identification: describe categories of affiliates (financial services affiliates, insurance affiliates, securities affiliates, etc.); identify specific affiliates by name if affiliate list is short; reference website if affiliate list is long; explain what affiliates do (insurance, securities, real estate, financial services). Information Sharing Practices: disclose what customer information is shared with affiliates (name, address, transaction information, account information, credit information, etc.); disclose how information is used by affiliates (marketing, underwriting, account servicing, fraud prevention, etc.); disclose whether information is shared for marketing purposes (yes/no/only with opt-out right). Opt-Out Mechanism Disclosure: explain customer right to opt-out of affiliate information sharing (except for account servicing, underwriting, fraud prevention, legal compliance); provide opt-out methods (mail, phone, online, in-person); provide specific instructions for each opt-out method; provide contact information (address, phone number, website). Opt-Out Effectiveness: explain when opt-out becomes effective (typically 30 days); explain duration of opt-out (ongoing unless revoked); explain how to revoke opt-out; explain that opt-out applies to all affiliates. Accuracy Requirement: privacy notice must accurately reflect actual practices; notice must match institution's actual affiliate information sharing; if notice says information is shared for X purpose, institution must actually share for X purpose; material differences between notice and practice constitute violation. Clear and Conspicuous Standard: notice must be easily readable; clear language; understandable explanations; not hidden in fine print; format allows easy location of key information; font size and contrast sufficient for readability. Initial Delivery: provided at account opening; given to customer before entering into customer relationship; provided in writing (paper or electronic); customer must acknowledge receipt; maintained for customer records. Annual Delivery: delivered annually without request; may be provided with annual statement; may be provided separately; frequency: once per year minimum; timing: at account anniversary or annually. Delivery Methods: paper mail; electronic (email) if customer agrees; website posting with customer notification; automated delivery systems; multiple methods available if customer preference differs. Affiliate List Options: Option 1 - List all affiliates by name; comprehensive list provided in notice; updated regularly; sent with notice. Option 2 - Describe affiliate categories; general categories described; reference website for specific names; affiliate list maintained on website. Option 3 - Combination; some major affiliates listed; categories described; reference to website for complete list. Website Posting: if affiliate list on website; website prominently links to privacy notice; affiliate list easily findable; updated regularly when affiliates change; accessible format (printable, downloadable). Notice Accuracy Testing: institution should verify notice accuracy; compare notice to actual practices; identify discrepancies; correct inaccuracies promptly. Notice Updates: update when affiliates change (new affiliates acquired, affiliates divested); update when information sharing practices change; update when opt-out mechanisms change; update when regulatory guidance changes; documentation of changes maintained. Multi-Language Notices: if institution serves non-English speaking customers; notice provided in primary customer language; Spanish notices common; other languages per customer demographics. Examination Review: examiners review privacy notice; compare to GLBA requirements; compare to actual practices; test whether disclosure accurate; test whether delivery procedures followed; evaluate clarity and conspicuousness; identify deficiencies. Common Notice Issues: inadequate affiliate identification; unclear information sharing explanation; missing or inadequate opt-out mechanism; inaccurate information sharing disclosure; privacy notice not delivered; not updated annually; not clear and conspicuous; inconsistency with actual practices.
